Question: get number of bytes a DataOutputStream wrapped around Socket.getOutputStream wrote: :I have a server-client application and using java Sockets API.  The server will send bytes to the client by calling DataOutputStream's write(bytes[] b), the DataOutputStream is wrapped around client.getOutputStream directly(no Buffer here).   This is a file download functionality And I'm going to support resume, I didn't use any HTTP here, I've implemented my own simple protocol.  I've seen these questions on SO :1-question1.2-C# question.3-FileChannel question.   The first doesn't answer my question, I can't wrap DataOutputStream around ByteArrayOutputStream because the latter can't be wrapped around client.getOutputStream and I don't know how to implement my own write(int i) method(And don't want to use JNI).   the second is C# not java(and it's calling WIN API anyway, I'm a linux user by the way :) ).   The third is talking about FileChannels and HTTP, As I said I'm not using HTTP and I'm using java Socket's API.  So how to get how many bytes were actually written ?PS (EDIT)By resume support I mean I'll give the client the ability to stop download at specific byte and then after a while(minutes,hours,days,whatever) he/she can resume download from where it has left.   
Please using this api: DataOutputStream.write.
Answer:<<<api>>>: DataOutputStream.write
<<<code>>>: int byteCount = dataOutputStream.size();
<<<explanation>>>: The DataOutputStream class in Java does not have a built-in method to get the number of bytes written to it. However, you can keep track of the number of bytes written by yourself by keeping a counter. When you call the write(int i) method, increment the counter. Here is an example:

```java
DataOutputStream dataOutputStream = new DataOutputStream(client.getOutputStream());
int byteCount = 0;

// Write some bytes
for (int i = 0; i < bytes.length; i++) {
    dataOutputStream.write(bytes[i]);
    byteCount++;
}

// Now byteCount contains the number of bytes written
```

This is a simple solution and may not work for all cases. For example, if you call the write(byte[] b) method, the number of bytes written will be the length of the array, not the number of bytes written by the write(int i) method. But for the write(int i) method, this solution should work fine.

Please note that this solution does not work if you call the write(byte[] b) method, because the number of bytes written by the write(byte[] b) method is not the same as the number of bytes written by the write(int i) method. If you need to track the number of bytes written by the write(byte[] b) method, you will need to implement your own write(byte[] b) method that increments a counter for each byte written.

Also, this solution does not work if you call the write(byte[] b, int off, int len) method, because the number of bytes written by the write(byte[] b, int off, int len) method is not the same as the number of bytes written by the write(int i) method. If you need to track the number of bytes written by the write(byte[] b, int off, int len) method, you will need to implement your own write(byte[] b, int off, int len) method that increments a counter for each byte written.

In conclusion, the Java DataOutputStream class does not have a built-in method to get the number of bytes written to it. You will need to implement your own solution to track the number of bytes written.
